Dear Ms. LeFear:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. No
substantial violations were found.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 248-860 0787.
Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
2023C0000166
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP250201139
Licensee Group Organization: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Designee: Demetrius LuJuan Starling
Chief Administrator: Kimberlee Lefear
Agency Name: Genesee County DHHS
Agency Address: 125 E UNION ST
FLINT, MI 48502-2036
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 04/18/2024
Capacity:

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Staff Responsibilities Rule 400.12207
Section (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be directly
Description responsible for all of the following activities:
(a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home care. Social
service workers shall work directly with the children, their families,
and other relevant individuals and be primarily responsible for the
development, implementation, and review of service plans for the
children and their families.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency did not provide services to Youth A related to her
special needs, by assisting the foster family in getting needed
services, inclusive of CMH and respite services.
Investigation Interviews:
Foster Parent B
On 1/13/2023, I interviewed Foster Parent B/the Complainant by
telephone. Foster Parent B reported his second concern with this
agency Genesee County (GC)-DHHS (Department of Health and
Human Services) is the lack of help he was getting from GC-
DHHS related to getting services for Youth A’s special needs. He
said Youth A’s special needs includes Mild Autism, Mood Disorder
Mild Cognitive Impairment, and possible Fetal Alcohol Syndrome.
He said he resides in Monroe, and he understood there would be
some coordination of services, but he should not have had to do
everything. He had to do all the work with Community Mental
Health (CMH) and to get Youth A’s records, from the Lighthouse
Rehabilitation Center where Youth A received prior treatment.
2

Foster Parent B reported, nor did GC-DHHS help him get services
related to Youth A’s Autism and special needs. GC-DHHS kept
telling him they didn’t’ know how to, but so many of the things he
tried to set up required GC-DHHS involvement. He said the
agency never explained/told him about a SED Waiver, whether he
could get this service, or if the SED Waiver and Wraparound
services were connected or the same. The agency also never got
him respite services that the worker told him he was eligible for.
GC-DHHS said there were none in his area, so he was out of luck.
He said other County CMH families, and Community services
persons saw he was struggling and assisted him. The CMH in
Monroe got his respite and wraparound services in place. He said
Youth A was receiving ABA (Applied Behavior Analysis) therapy
services (services for children on the autism spectrum). Those
services ended in October 2022 and GC-DHHS did not act to get
Youth A services reinstated via another provider. He reported it
has only been recently that GC-DHHS has tried to assist him. He
said FCW 6 was assigned to Youth A’s case in December 2022;
and in the last three weeks FCW 6 has been assisting him. He
said, FCW 5 and FCW 5’s supervisor did not do their job on Youth
A’s case. He said he had to do everything including medication
changes and reviews; trying to get prior services records for Youth
A and school records, all of which were records that could help get
needed services for Youth A.
Agency Staff Interviews
Administrator 2, Supervisor 3, Supervisor 4
On 2/2/2023 I had a special investigation onsite entrance
conference with Administrator 2, Supervisor 3, and Supervisor 4,
at which time I reviewed the allegations with them.
Supervisor 3 reported the allegation to be false. She said they
were involved with CMH immediately, but it took some time to get
services in place due to there being a cross-county situation.
Youth A also had gone inpatient for a while in 2021; and after
Youth A came back Youth A was working with a therapy in the
foster home. Youth A was connected with ABA service (A type of
service- not a provider) related to her Autism needs. Foster
Parent B was on a wait list for two providers in his area.
Supervisor 3 reported Foster Parent B3 wanted to work with one
specific provider, and this is why he was on a wait list. While
Foster Parent B waited, Service Person C was still involved with
Youth A and Foster Parent B in the foster home.
3

Supervisor 3 reported the agency did not address the SED Waiver
because they were waiting on the ABA services. She said Youth A
may have been eligible for both services, but FCW 5 may not
have known that. She said Youth A was eligible for respite in
Foster Parent B’s area, but none were available. That there were
no providers in the foster parent’s area to facilitate the respite.
She reported with respect to school records for Youth A, Foster
Parent B worked at the school that Youth A was attending at the
time and could have accessed the school records. She said FCW
5 could speak more to those records being requested.
Administrator 2 reported respite may be available in Youth A’s
area now; and FCW 6 can assist Foster Parent B with exploring
those. She said given that Foster Parent B is getting a level III
DOC for Youth A, Foster Parent B may be eligible for assisted
care, but that must be applied for. The agency will check on this
and assist with that now.
Foster Care Worker (FCW)5
On 2/2/2023 I interviewed FCW 5 onsite. She was the FCW for
Youth A until October 2022. She reported various information in
the complaint is not factual. She reported prior to Youth A
receiving ABA services, Youth A had in home mental health
services via Service Person C. She said, when Youth A was first
placed with Foster Parent B she reached out to CMH to get
services in place in Monroe. She said Foster Parent B
stonewalled the CMH case manager. She said getting the referral
and intake occurred quickly. Getting the evaluation via CMH to
determine the level of services Youth A would require took some
time due Foster Parent B not making and maintaining contact with
CMH to get everything set up. FCW 5 explained that then Youth
A began having manic episodes and was hospitalized at Harbor
Oaks for a couple of months (MISACWIS showed this time as
5/23/2021-7/9/2021). While Youth A was hospitalized Foster
Parent B was involved on the case and there were meetings with
him. Suggestions were made to him on how he could assist Youth
A in home with her needs. Meetings included FCW 5, Foster
Parent B, the CMH supervisor, FCW 5, Supervisor 3 and Youth
A’s adoption worker. During one meeting Foster Parent B made a
formal complaint against the CMH case manager which lead to
CMH pushing forward and getting in home-based therapy in place
with Service Person C. Service Person C went to the home three
times a week and worked with Youth A on Youth A’s
understanding her emotions, how to deal with them; her triggers,
social issues and calming exercises.
4

FCW 5 reported there were only two ABA Early Autism providers
in Foster Parent B’s area, and Foster Parent B wanted a specific
one, so any delay in services was related to the transfer. She said
Service Person C’s services ended in 2022 when ABA Early
Autism services started, which was around April or May 2022. The
ABA services were also home-based and similar services
provided by Service Person C, but more intensive. FCW 5
denied Foster Parent B having to go out of his way to get any of
the services in place. She said Service Person C had
recommended the provider Foster Parent B chose to go with.
Foster Parent B would just have been following up on that
recommendation. FCW 5 acknowledged Foster Parent B may
have also looked for programs; and may have asked his sister for
advice, because his sister has a child on the spectrum.
FCW 5 denied there being a length of time that Youth A was
without services prior to her going on medical leave of absence in
October 2022. She said the service hours had reduced due to the
supervisor and worker at the ABA provider agency quitting.
Youth A went from having 15 hours a week to just one session a
week, with the director providing those services. The director
reported she was trying to get more staff. FCW 5 said Foster
Parent B asked her whether he should try to get on another
service provider’s list or wait until this current service provider hire
more staff. FCW 5 said, she knew the other ABA provider would
be the one Foster Parent B did not choose the first time around;
so, she advised Foster Parent B that GC-DHHS would support
whatever decision Foster Parent B made. FCW 5 admitted to
learning the director at Youth A’s ABA service provider quit, just
before she went on her medical leave of absence. She said
before she left she spoke with FCW 7 about Youth A’s case
issues. She did not know what if anything FCW 7 followed up on
because she learned later that FCW 7 quit.
I asked FCW 5 about Foster Parent B getting respite and a SED
Waiver for services. FCW 5 said when Foster Parent B brought
respite up, she spoke with Service Person C about this. Service
Person C reported they did not have respite providers via CMH in
Foster Parent B’s area. Service Person C suggested that Foster
Parent B check with his relatives about being able to provide
respite. FCW 5 did not believe Foster Parent B had relatives who
could provide the level of help that Youth A required. She said
there was not much discussion with Foster Parent B about an
SED Waiver because, given his DOC level and the services
Foster Parent B was already getting, it was not different than what
would occur with the SED Waiver. She said the SED Waiver
5

would afford Youth A the classification, and enable her to get
specializes services, but Youth A was already getting the
specializes service. Foster Parent B was also getting Parent
support via CMH.
I also asked FCW 5 whether Foster Parent B had to get
medication and medication changes for Youth A. FCW 5 denied
Foster Parent B having to seek out Youth A’s medication or
changes to it. She said all of Youth A’s medications came with
Youth A when she was placed with Foster Parent B. Youth A was
set up with Dr. D. Dr. D monitored Youth A’s medication and
conducted her medication reviews. FCW 5 reported there was a
struggle with getting Youth A’s medication levels right, but Foster
Parent B’s work with the doctor would have been by way of
reporting how Youth A was adjusting to the medications. Foster
Parent B would have also been responsible for taking Youth A to
her medication reviews and reporting her behaviors to the
medication so that adjustments and or changes could be made if
warranted. This would have been a normal part of his role as a
foster parent.
Lastly I asked FCW 5 whether Foster Parent B had requested any
documents from her, inclusive of school record which may have
been needed to secure services for Youth A. FCW 5 said, Foster
Parent B had mentioned something about a possible sexual
allegation that a Casa Worker had mentioned to him. FCW 5
went back through Youth A’s record. She saw an old investigation
that mentioned something when Youth A was five or years old, but
the investigation could not conclude there was any truth a sexual
act against Youth A. She shared that information with Foster
Parent B. As for any school records, FCW 5 reported there was a
delay in getting school records from the Lighthouse Residential
placement where Youth A had attended. She said that facility
converted to an Adult Foster Care. She said that was back in
2020, and Youth A's new school needed to request those records
from the old school. FCW 5 reported that when Youth A was at
the Redford School, Foster Parent B was a special education
teacher there and would have had access to Youth A’s school
record. She said Foster Parent B has Youth A placed in the
Airport school district in Monroe County later; and when she left
for her medical leave there were no school records needed, or
issues in that area. She said she was not aware of a fetal alcohol
diagnosis for Youth A. She said the main issue of the case when
she left was Youth A’s delayed adoption due to a special
evaluation. She said Foster Parent B tends to make complaints
when he is frustrated and not getting his way.
6

Foster Care Worker (FCW) 6
I interviewed FCW 6 onsite on 2/2/2023. FCW 6 was assigned to
Youth A’s case on 12/19/2022. She met with Foster Parent B for
foster home visit on that date. Foster Parent B mentioned all of his
concerns at that home visit. Foster Parent B reported all of Youth
A’s services via ABA-Early Autism services terminated in October
2022. Foster Parent B said Youth A was getting around 30 hours
of services and those when down to four hour between August
and October of 2022. Foster Parent said Youth A’s services then
stopped completely. The latter was because that ABA service
provider/agency shut down because the workers, then the
supervisor and the director all quit. Foster Parent B told FCW 6
he was placed on “Illuminate’s” wait list, which is, another ABA
service provider. Foster Parent B reported, he had reached out to
FCW 5 about this. FCW 6 said she was not sure what all had
occurred before, because she was just learning all this from
Foster Parent B on her first visit with him.
FCW 6 reported Youth A’s services via Illuminated started in
January 2023. The service hours for now are limited (FCW 5 was
not sure of the number of hours) until the Illuminate service worker
completes all her required training. Thereafter, Youth A will get full
services. FCW 6 denied there was anything she had to do to get
this new services in place, but she reached out to CMH to inquire
whether there anything more she could do to get Youth A full
services sooner.
FCW 6 said no other services had fallen off for Youth A. She said
Foster Parent B asked about Wraparound, SED Waivers and
respite. Foster Parent B said FCW 5 told him he had to get
Wraparound or Respite. She told Foster Parent B she did not
know how they all those programs or services connected or
compared; she would check matters out and get back with him.
FCW 6 said, she contacted the CMH in Monroe and Youth A
showed in their system, Youth A CMH case manager reported that
an SED Waiver and Wraparound were in the works for Youth A.
FCW 6 reported based on the information she had learned; Youth
A will be eligible for both ABA services and a SED Waiver.
Foster Parent B will have to choose either Wrapround or respite,
either would allow for someone to come into the home to help and
give him a break.
FCW 6 said Foster Parent B did not mention any concerns related
to Youth A’s medication, medication reviews or him needing
school records or other records for Youth A.
7

Supervisor 8
I interviewed Supervisor 8 by telephone on 2/24/2023. She was
the supervisor to FCW 7, who had Youth A’s case for a short
period of time. FCW 7 resigned 12/15/2022/ is no longer with the
department. Supervisor 8 did recall FCW 7 mentioning an issue
related to Youth A’s case. Foster Parent B never reached out to
Supervisor 8 about Youth A’s case.
Document Review
MISACWIS case record for Youth A which showed:
• Youth A is and permanent ward of the court and adoption is
pending with Foster Parent B
• She was placed with Foster Parent B on 2/3/2021.
• She had a mental health hospital stay on 5/23/2021 and
was returned to Foster Parent B’s care on 7/9/2021.
• Her diagnoses include Autism Spectrum Disorder;
Adjustment Disorder with Disturbance of Conduct; Conduct
Disorder Unspecified; Cognitive Impairment.
• Youth A’s 9/21/2022-12/19/2022 Updated Service Plan that
showed a 10/3/2022 social work contact related to Youth
A’s ABA therapy reducing from 9-15 hours weekly to two
hours weekly due to staffing issue, and the director
providing those limited services. Also, a 10/14/2022
concern by Foster Parent B, denoting Youth A is regressing
without the full ABA services; and it being unfair that Youth
A must wait on a wait list. Additionally, a 11/7/2022 social
work contact home visit contact reporting by Foster Parent
B repeating that Youth A is regressing due to the ABA
service pause. He is looking to get Youth A into a provider
with a shorter wait list.
• An Early Autism service transfer report showing:
➢ Youth A date of admission as 2/1/2022 and date of
the transfer plan as 10/12/2022.
➢ Youth A was referred for ABA therapy services due
to concerns of aggressive and impulsive behavior.
She received an autism evaluation and confirmed
diagnosis through Monroe County CMH.
➢ The reason for transition indicated Youth A’s
treatment has been on hold since August of 2022,
due to a lack of staff. The program’s clinical director
has provided check in visits since the leave of her
previous providers to maintain continuity of care. At
this time, Youth A is transitioning from the care of
the current program, Autism Family Partnership
(AFP), to their sister program, Early Autism
8

Services, due to the ABA program’s clinical director
leaving. Also, that currently, the program does not
have a BCBA available to service Youth A’s case;
and she will remain on the waitlist for service
providers with Early Autism Services until staff are
available or an alternative program with availability
is identified.
➢ Youth A’s case manager at Monroe Community
Mental Health has been contacted and updated of
her status with the program. The Clinical Director is
available for coordination of care if another service
provider is identified.
Analysis Based on the interviews and documents reviewed there is
insufficient evidence to support that the agency did not provide or
seek to provide services for Youth A. Nor that there was a lack of
work with the child, family, or relevant individuals related to the
service plan.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
II. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan continuation of the agency’s
current licensing status is recommended.
May 2, 2023
__________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
May 9, 2023

Area Manager
